_prev_prog_3.Description: Sanger Poultry has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is in compliance with Californias Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements. At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program has been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs.,which is contained in our refrigeration system.

Sanger Poultry has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is in compliance with Californias Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements. At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program has been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs.,which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                   | Process Chemical          | Process Quantity(lbs.)

P1 - Ammonia Refrigeration       Anhydrous Ammonia           39,000

P2 - CST Ammonia Refrigeration   Anhydrous Ammonia           39,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and publi

c safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



Sanger Poultry operates a processing plant and freezer for poultry products that utilizes two (2) ammonia refrigeration systems.



1.2.1 Process 1



Process 1 provides refrigeration capacity to the following areas:

Cooler

Turkey Room

Cut Up Room

Air Chill Room

Blast Tunnels 1-4

Shell and Tube Water Chiller

Ice Maker



The Process 1 refrigeration system consists of (2) Vilter high-stage screw compressor packages, three (3) FES high-stage screw compressor packages, one (1) Mycom economized screw compressor package, one (1) low temperature recirculator package, one (1) high pressure receiver, and one (1) intercooler, all located in the central machinery room.

One (1) low-temperature pump recirculator package, one (1) high-pressure receiver, one (1) shell and tube water chiller with integral surge drum, and two (2) evaporative condensers are located outdoors in the immediate vicinity of the refrigeration machinery room. A third low-temperature pump recirculator package is located inside the back hallway in the processing area.



Twenty-eight (28) air cooling evaporator units and one (1) ice maker are also remotely served from the central machinery room.



The system utilizes pumped liquid recirculators where high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to a liquid recirculator or intercooler through a liquid feed solenoid valve and an expansion valve.  From there, low pressure liquid is further expanded into a lower pressure recirculator or is pumped to ea

ch cold room, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into an evaporator where low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator coils.  Low pressure and temperature gas and overfeed liquid passes through check valves and is returned to the liquid recirculators. The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculator and the suction gas is piped to the six (6) screw compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure ammonia gas is liquefied and returned to the two (2) high pressure receivers.



The Process 1 refrigeration system was built more than twenty-five years ago, but since that time the following projects have occurred:

May 2011 - Ice Makers were moved and a vertical liquid recirc package was installed outside to feed them

May 2012 - NH3 Plus installed a new evaporative condenser

July 2012 - APCCO installed Blast Cooler #4 and a new high pressure receiver

October 2014 - NH3 Plus removed the boiler room recirculator and repiped Blast Tunnel 4 so that it is now served from the Turkey Room Recirculator

1.2.2 Process 2



Process 2 provides refrigeration capacity to the following areas:

Cooler

(2) Freezers

Staging Area

Air Chill Room

43?F Processing Room

70?F Processing Room



The Process 2 refrigeration system is equipped with air-cooling evaporators and pump recirculators as required for pumped overfeed operation. All control valve groups are mounted on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within the refrigeration machinery room or directly outside near the machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:

(1) 84" Dia x 13'-9" Long +10?F Recirculator with (2) Integral Teikoku Ammonia Pumps

(1) 60" Dia x 12'-9" Long -20?F Recirculator with (2) Integral Teikoku Ammonia Pumps

(1) 84" Dia x 21'-10" High Pressure Receiver

(1) 30" Dia x 5'-7" Long Liquid Subcooler

(1) 42" Dia x 10'-0" Long Suction Accumulator

(1) 20" Dia x 3'-4" Long Liquid Transfer Vessel

(1) 30" Dia x 9'-0" Long Thermosyphon Receiver

(1) 7'-3" Dia x 18' Long Ammonia Diffusion Tank

(2) Frick XLP2-1236-2036 Evaporative Condensers

(1) Frick RWF II-316 600 HP Screw Compressor

(1) Frick RWF II-100 200 HP Screw Compressor

(1) Frick RWF II-222 437 HP Screw Compressor

(1) Frick RWF II-270 643 HP Screw Compressor

(2) Frick RWF II-270 600 HP Screw Compressors

(1) Machinery Room Ventilation System

(6) Penthouse Evaporators

(2) Ceiling Suspended Evaporators

(16) Air Chill Coils

(4) AcuAir Units with Integral Surge Drums



The Process 2 system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped through a liquid feed solenoid valve, an expansion valve, and into a liquid recirculator.  From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each evaporator, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into evaporator.  Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator.  As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the liquid recirculator.  The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculator and the gas is piped to the main suction accumulator and then the suction inlet on the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.

The refrigeration system was built in 2015-2016 by Cold Storage Technologies. The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent ammonia gas to a diffusion tank if the pressure in

the system exceeds their set point. Each entrance to a machinery room contains emergency refrigeration shutdown and ventilation controls for use during an emergency situation.



1.2.3 Summary



Each of the two (2) ammonia processes at Sanger Poultry consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping, but not interconnected or co-located with respect to each other. As such, Sanger Poultry has two (2) refrigeration processes.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 78,000 (LBS). It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equip

ment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry has had two (2) accidental release within the last five (5) years.



Incident Investigation # 2014-01

Date of incident: September 23, 2014

Accident duration: 15 minutes

Regulated substance released: Anhydrous Ammonia

Estimated quantity released: 2,700 lbs.

NAICS: 311615

Source: Anhydrous Ammonia release through a relief valve

Weather conditions: 68 degree F and calm

Onsite impacts: 34 injuries

Offsite impacts: None

Initiating event and contributing factors:The West Relief Valve on the Intercooler (PRV-11A) lifted and remained lifted for approximately 15 minutes.  This was due to a high level condition within the Intercooler (IC-1), which was caused by a faulty solenoid valve (LFSV-IC1) spring.



Offsite responders notified and responded



Recommendations: Operating Procedures | Additional Training | Engineering Changes



Incident Investigation # 2016-01

Date of incident: May 2, 2016

Accident duration: 46 minutes

Regulated substance released: Anhydrous Ammonia

Estimated quantity released: 1,538 lbs.

NAICS: 311615

Source: Anhydrous Ammonia release through failed Sporlan MA-17 liquid injection oil cooling solenoid valve on Compressor 7

Weather conditions: 86 degree F

Onsite impacts: 5 injuries

Offsite impacts: None

Initiating event and contributing factors:

Failed liquid cooling solenoid valve on Compressor 7. The failure appears to be the result of metal fatigue or a manufacture defect.

Offsite responders notified and responded

Recommendations:

Emergency Notification Checklist Update.

Replace the failed Sporlan MA-17 liquid injection oil cooling solenoid valve on Compressor 7.





1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38



Stra

tegically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framewor

k that guides safe action for Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Pitman Farms - Sanger Poultry will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
